content: The "Bipartisan Earmark Reform Commission Act of 2008" establishes the Bipartisan Earmark Reform Commission to carry out specific duties. The Bipartisan Earmark Reform Commission Act of 2008 establishes a Commission to define earmarks and analyze their policy implications, including trends, effects on for-profit companies, disparities in distribution, impacts on the budget, and effects on specific departments and agencies. The Commission established by the Bipartisan Earmark Reform Commission Act of 2008 will analyze the policy implications of earmarks, including their distribution among Members, departments, and agencies, the use of a merit-based application process, transparency in disclosure, executive branch earmarking, disparities in earmark recipients, and the naming of projects after members of Congress. The naming of projects after current or retired members of Congress or executive branch officials is a key aspect analyzed by the Commission established by the Bipartisan Earmark Reform Commission Act of 2008. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed by various leaders, with a mix of political affiliations. The President designates a chairperson and co-chairperson, ensuring bipartisan representation. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed by various leaders, with bipartisan representation. If a member appointed as a Member of Congress ceases to be one, they will no longer be part of the Commission. Meetings are called by the chairperson or majority of members, with a quorum of seven members required for decisions. The Commission consists of 12 members appointed with bipartisan representation. Meetings are called by the chairperson or majority of members, with a quorum of seven members required for decisions. The Director and staff of the Commission are outlined in Section 5. The Commission appoints a director responsible for administration and coordination, with the authority to appoint additional staff. The director and staff may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws. The Commission appoints a director responsible for administration and coordination, with the authority to appoint additional staff. The director and staff may be appointed and paid without following certain civil service laws. The competitive service allows for pay up to $150,000 per year, and experts and consultants can be procured by the director as needed. The director can procure experts and consultants under appropriation Acts at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 6. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission has the authority to hold hearings, take testimony, receive evidence, administer oaths, and use the United States mails. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission, and administrative support services can be provided upon request. The Commission can receive administrative support services on a reimbursable basis and enter into contracts to fulfill its duties under the Act. The Commission established by the Act must submit a detailed report with findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative and administrative reforms within six months. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its final report. Congressional leaders must introduce legislation recommended by the Commission within 60 legislative days of the report submission.
